results.title: The City Speaks
results.creator_credit: Crawford Productions and Housing Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Made in 1965 showing the provision of housing for Melbourne’s growing population, 50,000 of whom live in 1,000 acres of inner suburban slums. Following demolition, large block of flats provide the amenities and home comforts for low income families at low rentals where children can play happily in well planned playgrounds. The historic footage of the demolition of inner city dwellings to accommodate high rise housing commission flats and the intentions behind the move are interesting to view in retrospect.

results.title: Begonia festival
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Boolari Films and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: At the annual Begonia Festival, Ballarat becomes a city of flowers, music, dancing and drama centred on the famous begonia display. Mr. Tom Beaumont, the curator of the glass house in the Botanic Gardens, tends the many blooms. He is a world authority on begonia culture. Highlights of the display are a thousand double blooms and six hundred distinctive single varieties. In the gardens we see a fine display of salvias, gladioli and dahlias. Young and old admire the wonderful colour and variety of the Botanic Gardens and also the open air art exhibition. Commentary by John Morgan.

results.brief_description: Magazine items: Adelaide dog show; Bronzetti wins the Caulfield Cup against Chrome and Rael Loein; Rocket wins the Sydney Flying Squadron’s handicap in the opening event of the sailing season on Sydney Harbour and 85 unions are represented at the annual eight hour day demonstrations.

results.title: Alpine Playground
results.creator_credit: Cinesound and Tourist Development Authority of Victoria
results.brief_description: A holiday with a difference; the joys of an alpine winter holiday in Victoria’s picturesque skiing resorts, Mt Buffalo, Mt Hotham and Falls Creek. Within easy reach of Melbourne, facilities include expert ski instruction, readily available ski tows, toboggans, and comfortable accommodation.

results.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
results.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

constellations_primary.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_primary.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

results.description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
description_for_label: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.

results.title: Tomatoes for processing
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Ann Millard, Jack Keane and Rod Kefford
results.brief_description:
Film begins with instructions on how to garner and prepare tomato seeds for planting, before focusing on the seed germination process and how to cultivate a good crop of seedlings.

The seedlings are then uprooted and planted in larger fields. Manual and semi-automatic seedling planting techniques are shown using different types of machinery.

When fully grown the tomatoes are picked and packed into wooden crates. Film details the correct picking and packing process.

Finally, the tomatoes are taken to a factory, where they are pulped and made into tomato sauce.

results.title: Global insights 4
results.creator_credit: Ntennis Davi, Campbell Manderson, Tom McKendrick and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
Global Insights 4 is a compilation of short video works of a subversive political nature, sourced from videoactivists, cultural saboteurs and ‘serious’ documentary-makers from around the world.
Pieces featured include an alternative US response to the incidents of September 11 2001, made by Indymedia NYC soon after the event; scenes from the front line of the democracy struggle in Malaysia. A remarkable sequence of (unarmed) indigenous peasants in Mexico taking over an army base; a Korean perspective on the rise of the new global economic orthodoxy and the resistance to it; the ‘no borders’ movement in Europe and Australia against the deportation and detention of refugees.
Adverts peppered throughout the program are actually ‘subverts’ - biting satirical 30-second statements about consumerism, gender, sexuality and possibilities for reshaping the world. Producers of this form range from disaffected advertisers to teenagers with an ironic message about climate change.
The Global Insights videos have seen hundreds of free public screenings from Tamil Nadu to Antarctica - inspiring grass-roots people’s action and fostering an independent and accessible screen culture globally.
Global Insights is put together on a miniscule budget by volunteers. It is a collaboration between hundreds of independent media makers around the world.

results.title: Access News greatest hits 2000. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
Access News Greatest Hits 2000 (Part 1 of 2)
SKA TV’s Access News is a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
Giving light to perspectives or issues otherwise not seen, stories range from front-line coverage of anti-globalisation protests to satirical critiques of commercial media.
‘Greatest Hits 2000’ is a compilation of 15 of Access News’s best stories from the year 2000.
Highlights from part 1:
Violence is Violence : Hundreds of Sydney residents take over the streets to protest car-dominated public space and offer a vision of urban sustainability. Their celebration is met with a brutal police response.
Fire Water Earth : The world’s largest uranium mine is located at Roxby Downs in South Australia. It is owned by multinational mining corporation WMC and is built on Arabunna and Kokotha land. This story follows the nuclear trail from an occupation of a WMC borefield by Arabunna elder Kevin Buzzacott and his supporters to a daring mission by videoactivists into the heart of WMC headquarters in Melbourne, surprising the boss himself.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV

results.title: A Good Eye for Story
results.credit_line:
Filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)
Equipment provided by Panavision Australia
Colour by Matt Fezz
Special thanks to CAAMA Productions
results.material_description: Single-channel video, HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 3:06 min
results.brief_description: Dylan River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

constellations_other.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_other.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

results.headline_credit_for_label:
filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)

Equipment provided by Panavision Australia

Colour by Matt Fezz
results.description:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River
description_for_label:
